OMG, 9 years ago 😭

A screensaver's entire purpose to is "save the screen" from burn in, by not leaving any static images on the screen for a long period of time. Many of these screensavers wouldn't actually work for this purpose, such as the clock ones which would burn the letters into your screen permanently if you left it on for too long. Of course, the original phosphor burn-in issues that CRTs and plasmas have aren't really a thing with modern displays, but the recent popularity of OLED displays means that burn-in may still be an issue for some people.

Of course, I understand that screensavers have moved beyond simply the original utilitarian purpose they were designed for, but I still think it's interesting that many of these screensavers don't actually save your screen.

The Zhuk-class patrol boat, also known as Project 1400M "Grif", is a Soviet border patrol vessel. At least 130 boats built between 1969 and 1996. Exact numbers are unknown, but they were widely exported by the Soviet Union in addition to use in home waters as harbor patrol. The vessels were excellent for this task thanks to a cheap design for mass production. With only a single simple radar unit and manually-aimed machine guns, they made ideal patrol boats. The dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, and the abolishment of its primary user the, KGB Maritime Guard, it was taken over by the Russian Federal Coast Guard. By 2007 only 15-20 remained in service with the Russian Navy.

When monitors used to be larger than dinosaurs and used cathode ray-tube technology, they could get something called phosphor burn. The basic idea of this is that if the monitor displayed the same image for extended periods of time, the image would be burned into the screen permanently. The solution was to make screensavers, which changed the image on the screen continously to prevent phosphor burn.
